quests.name: No-body said Aliens
quests.description: As a great industrial magnate, you don't need relics from long-dead super civilizations to perform hard sci-fi calculations.  Just write your own circuit presses (if you have a HV laser engraver), or get an earthly sponsor.

tasks.longDescription: You can make extra Presses of ones you have by putting it and any Solid Iron or Steel Block in any tier of Press, or use the dedicated Inscriber.

quests.name: Energy Conversion
quests.description: An ME System normally runs on internal AE, but Greggy-EU will work (the AE system has a HV limit before EXPLODING). You can convert RF, EU, or shaft power into AE by connecting it into the Energy Acceptor and piping it out with Fluix Cables or Quartz Fibres. You can also supply power through the ME Controller, but then that is one less side you can pull channels from.

tasks.longDescription: 1EU = 2 AE. 1 AE = 2 RF. 160 Nm * rad/s = 1 AE/t

quests.name: So Many Channels, Nothing On
quests.description: The ME Controller gives you more channels to work with. Each side adds 8 or 32 channels. It can also accept energy and convert it to AE. It is an extended structure that can look like whatever neural ganglion you feel like, but you can only have one per ME System.

tasks.longDescription: The ME Controller also accepts RF and EU to power the ME system, but that is one less side you can use channels with.

quests.name: Made Out of Buttons and Wires
quests.description: AE2 machines are hooked up and powered via Fluix conduits. Channels are a very special mechanic: most Busses or AE2 Machines take up a channel. ME glass or smart cables can only transfer 8 channels, and can have busses attached to them. The Dense ME Cable carries 32 channels but does not operate busses nor terminals.

tasks.longDescription: ME Glass Cables can only carry 8 channels. You can connect Busses and terminals to them.
ME Smart Cables can also only hold 8 Channels at once, but you see a visual representation of them. You can hook up Busses and/or terminals with them also.
ME Dense Cables can carry 32 channels, and you can see a visual representation of them. However, you cannot connect Busses nor terminals to them.

quests.name: ME Wire Coils
quests.description: These Wire Coils function similar to other Wire Coils from Immersive Engineering. The Transformers are connector-like (but big), the Connectors are relay-like (without the placement restriction of HV).
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: Touch ME Cables to the ME Transformer, then connect via ME Wire Connectors and Fluix Wire Coils to another ME Transformer and the rest of your ME System. This tier can only hold 8 channels, and can have 24 blocks in between ME Wire Connectors.

Touch ME Cables to the ME Dense Transformer, then connect via ME Dense Wire Connectors and Dense Wire Coils to another ME Dense Transformer and the rest of your ME System. This tier can hold 32 channels, and can have 16 blocks in between ME Dense Wire Connectors.

quests.name: Not Actually Floppy
quests.description: Storage Cells are placed into the ME Drive. Every Storage Cell can only take 63 unique items, but the different tiers can hold certain amounts of bytes. 8 items take up 1 byte, no matter the size of a regular stack. Going straight for the max size Storage Cell isn't necessarily the best idea, because then you still only have 63 possible unique items, even if it's a lot more of those 63 items.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: I won't ask you to make any specific Storage Cell, as depending on where you are you can afford larger ones.

quests.name: Accessing Your Stuff
quests.description: The ME Crafting Terminal allows you to access items stored in your ME Storage Cells, and has an in-built crafting table.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The ME Crafting Terminal connects to an ME Cable, and takes up 1 channel.

quests.name: The Wheels on the Bus
quests.description: No, not that kind of bus. These Busses are essentially ways to interact with things outside of the ME System. These all take a channel each.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The Import Bus pulls items from an inventory in front of it into the ME System it is connected to. For example, if you want to move all your items out of chests into your ME System, you would use a Dolly to move all your chests so that they're connected to an Import Bus, which will suck out all the items and put them into the System. You can set a whitelist on what to import by opening it and putting items into it. By default, the whitelist can only have 1. With 2 Capacity Cards, it can have 9.

The Export Bus pushes items out of the ME System into the inventory it is facing. You have to open the Bus and put the items you want to push out into it. Without Capacity Cards, you only can export 1 item. With 2 Capacity Cards, you can export 9.

The Storage Bus allows you to access inventories that are not a part of the ME system. If you place it facing, for instance, a Drawer Controller, you won't have to get rid of your entire wall of Drawers; instead, you'll be able to access them all from ME Terminals. This way, you won't waste precious Storage Cell space.

quests.name: Autocrafting
quests.description: AE2's probably best feature is Autocrafting. This allows you to automatically craft whatever you define, which saves a surprising amount of time. But it takes a modicum of infrastructure.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The Crafting CPU is a multiblock. It must be a cuboid, meaning it has 6 sides maximum. It is made up of Crafting Co-Processing Units and Crafting Storages. The more Crafting CPUs, the more parts can be crafted in parrallel. The more Crafting Storage you have, the more complicated of a recipe you can make. Having multiple Multiblocks allows you to autocraft multiple things at once.

The ME Pattern Terminal allows you to set recipes that can be autocrafted, either through regular crafting or through machines. You need Blank Patterns to begin with. For crafting table recipes, input the recipe to the crafting table gui to the left and hit the Encode Pattern Button and pull out the Encoded Pattern.  Be aware that all tools used in a Gregtech6 crafting recipe must be replaced with their "Robot Arm" versions in an autocrafting pattern. For processing patterns, for instance Roll Bender or other things like that, click the Crafting Table to the right to switch modes. Then, put the inputs to the left and outputs to the right. Keep clicking to put more of the same item in if you need multiple or receive multiple of one of the items.

The ME Interface is where you connect your ME System to processing or crafting. For processing, put the ME Interface (preferably the panel version, as you can put multiple in one block, and you easily specify which side of the cable) next to a machine, like a Wiremill. Then, put a processing recipe into the bottom slots of the ME Interface. Connect an Import Bus to the machine's output face to pull the finished item back into the ME System. Bingo presto! Automatic processing! For regular crafting, see the next task. ME Interfaces take up a channel each.

Molecular Assemblers perform the crafting grid recipes. They require a ME Interface to hold their patterns, and AE power (which they transmit). Unlike other processing machines, they put their products back into the attached interfaces automatically.

quests.name: Dimensional Box
quests.description: The ME Wireless Access Point and Wireless Terminal allow you to wirelessly access your ME System's contents.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The ME Wireless Access Point is the central location that you have to be nearby to in order to use the Wireless Terminal. You can extend the range with Wireless Boosters at the cost of more AE/t usage.

The ME Security Terminal is how you bind your Wireless Terminal to the ME System. Place the Wireless Terminal in the top right and it will bind to that system. Biometric cards can also be used herein to limit permissions for any person (including yourself), and set default permissions.
The Wireless Terminal is essentially an ME Access Terminal that you can hold.

quests.name: MagiTech Crafting
quests.description: The Arcane Crafting Terminal works as a regular Crafting Terminal AND an Arcane Worktable. You put your Wand in there, and craft like normal, but you have access to your entire ME System while doing it.

quests.name: Electric Fluids
quests.description: The ME Fluid Terminal allows you to access fluids in your ME System. You need to have Fluid Storage in your ME System to store fluids in it.

tasks.longDescription: Put the thing you want to put the fluid into (bucket/can/whatever) into the left slot, and click what you want to put into it. Or, you can put a filled fluid container into the left slot, and it will go into the system.

quests.name: Information MagiTechnology
quests.description: The Essentia Terminal allows you to access Essentia in your ME System. To store Essentia in your ME System, you need Essentia Storage Cells.

tasks.longDescription: Only these magical chips can run the septinary code required for essentia storage natively.

quests.name: Now With USB4 Compatibility
quests.description: The Wireless Universal Terminal gains new modes by crafting together with an Access Terminal of a new type (items, fluids, gasses, essentia). To switch modes, shift right click it.

tasks.longDescription: To add a mode, craft a Wireless Terminal with an Access Terminal that you want to add support for. To make the max upgraded one, craft the regular Wireless Access Terminal with either a Fluid Terminal or Essentia Terminal, then craft that with the other one, and finally with a vanilla crafting table.

quests.name: Amphibious Bus Tour
quests.description: These Busses work exactly the same as the regular ones, but with Fluids.

quests.name: Magic School Bus
quests.description: These Busses work exactly the same as the regular ones, but with Essentia.

quests.name: Magical Autocrafting
quests.description: With these machines you will be able to automatically craft things that usually would require an Arcane Worktable.

tasks.longDescription:
The Knowledge Inscriber works similar to the Pattern Terminal. Instead of Patterns, you need the Knowledge Core. Put in the recipe and save it to the Knowledge Core. The Knowledge Core can have 21 Recipes in it. 
 Instead of putting patterns in a connected terminal(s), the Arcane Assembler takes one Knowledge Core internally. Therefore, unlike the normal Molecular Assembler, the Arcane Assembler does take up a network channel.

quests.name: Automated Automated Alchemy
quests.description: The Essentia Provider allows Thaumcraft machines to access Essentia from your ME System.

tasks.longDescription: It acts like a giant Buffer Tube.

quests.name: Mirror Mirror
quests.description: The Infusion Provider allows the Infusion Altar to use Essentia directly from your ME System.

tasks.longDescription: Place it as if it was the jar nearby your altar.

quests.name: Entanglo-portation
quests.description: There are some places it is just impossible to run (dense) cable to, like other planets or planes of existence. For those situations, AE2 suggests the creation of an artifically stabilized Einstein-Rosen bridge, better known as a micro wormhole. No coherent matter can pass through, but thankfully you have in place a system to transmit and store material as pure information.

tasks.longDescription: Bending space-time into a wormhole first requires an excessively dense gravity field, that is a really heavy and super-compressed ball of matter. A quarter million junk items should do the trick.

Some force will be required to split the singularity into two linked parts, which can then be individually moved while remaining linked inside. 

 Who knew a minor concussive explosion would be enough?

Transdimensional I/O operations in the AE network require a horizontal ring around the core, into which the specific quantum-linked singularity will be placed. The ring has four (or twelve?) contacts for cable, and can transmit at least those 128 channels. 
 Note that these structures do not care about distance, and could even be used as long-range, or simply wireless, connections on the same world.

quests.name: Welcome to the Matrix
quests.description:
Having so successfully digitized and uploaded material, it is time to attempt the transmogrification of living creatures... 
 Well, we can't do that directly, but it does work indirectly by virtualizing the entire patch of space-time in which the entity resides.

tasks.longDescription:
Time to brush up on subnets (or just build it seperately); each network can only contain ONE Spatial I/O Port, and exactly THREE Spatial Pylons. The Pylons must be offset from the IO Port along each of the cardinal axes, as they define the region that will be scanned in to (or re-constituted from) the disk in it. 
 Apply a rising edge redstone signal to the I/O Port to swap the contents of the disk and the space. This will only work if the local network has (Dense) Energy Cells with sufficient charge to INSTANTLY supply the full energy cost of transmogrificating every entity and block in the space.

The category of Spatial storage Disk defines the maximum side length of zone that can be scanned onto it by a Spatial I/O Port. 
 Upon exploration, it turns out that entire cubic volume is made available in some virtual meta-reality. The Spatial Storage is a sort of key to the specific demi-plane, allowing parts of it to be swapped with whatever is inside the Spatial Pylons each time the Spatial I/O Port is activated with it. Time passes normally for all things in these demi-planes, one could even construct an inter-dimensional teleporter to access them directly (Stargates anyone?); Without such an internal link, the Spatial storage Disk would be the only way to access the contents of that demi-plane. 
 One could get tricky with Quantum Link Chambers and a bookshelf.
